title: In which cases should I use the different types of narrators while writing a story? - Quora

response.answer_text: Only switch narrators if the scope of the story requires it. Essentially, if there is no way the protagonist can reasonably be exposed to information critical to the story plot. In basic practice, each additional viewpoint adds about 4x as much housekeeping including but not limited to : That character’s back story, front storyThat character’s wants and needsThat character’s stakes and motivationsThat character’s goals and epiphanyThat character’s immediate side cast and THEIR upkeepSo, it’s hard enough to do one character well— doing all the above. If you have two or three, you SHOULD do the same justice to each. I find that most writers add another character without sufficient justification and generally weaken the narrative… because their motivation was a some trivial revelation that totally wasn’t worth the extra dilution. See my article on developing character / milieu here: Will Greenway's post in Writing Challenges If big casts are your thing I have a whole article series on dealing with that: Writing: Handling a Cast of Thousands (1 of 3) Writing: Handling a Cast of Thousands (2 of 3) Writing: Handling a Cast of Thousands (3 of 3)
